options.text: The lambs were born with one eye.

options.label: B
options.text: It tells cells to release a protein that promotes cell growth.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: In Ancient Greece, who discovered that some quantities, like the diagonal of a square with sides of length one, couldn't be expressed by any combination of whole numbers or fractions?
Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals initially banned in Florence in the 13th century?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They were considered easier to forge or alter, and the concept of zero opened the door to negative numbers and debt recording.

options.text: They were associated with a rival city-state.

options.label: C

title: Should we get rid of standardized testing? - Arlo Kempf

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of the first standardized tests administered in China over 2,000 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine aptitude for various government posts

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate language proficiency for diplomats

options.label: C
options.text: To assess stair-climbing abilities for firefighters

options.label: D
options.text: To measure academic learning in schools

multiple-choice.question: What is a percentile, and how is it used to express test results?

options.label: A
options.text: A percentile is a measure of the number of questions answered correctly, and it is used to express test results in relation to a set of fixed criteria.

options.label: B
options.text: A percentile is a measure of the percentage of test-takers who scored below a certain score, and it is used to express test results in relation to the results of other test-takers.

options.label: C
options.text: A percentile is a measure of the time it takes to complete a test, and it is used to express test results in relation to a set of fixed criteria.

options.label: D
options.text: A percentile is a measure of the number of questions answered incorrectly, and it is used to express test results in relation to the results of other test-takers.

multiple-choice.question: What are some limitations of standardized tests, and how can they be addressed?

options.label: A
options.text: Standardized tests are limited in their ability to measure abstract characteristics or skills, and this can be addressed by designing tests differently.

options.label: B
options.text: Standardized tests are limited in their ability to measure academic learning, and this can be addressed by using different types of assessments.

options.label: C
options.text: Standardized tests are limited in their ability to measure test anxiety, and this can be addressed by providing accommodations for students with test anxiety.

options.label: D
options.text: Standardized tests are limited in their ability to measure cultural familiarity, and this can be addressed by using culturally sensitive test questions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between reliability and validity in the context of standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Reliability refers to the consistency of test results, while validity refers to the accuracy of test results.

options.label: B
options.text: Reliability refers to the accuracy of test results, while validity refers to the consistency of test results.

options.label: C
options.text: Reliability refers to the ability of a test to measure what it is intended to measure, while validity refers to the ability of a test to produce consistent results.

options.label: D
options.text: Reliability refers to the ability of a test to produce consistent results, while validity refers to the ability of a test to measure what it is intended to measure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern of social scientists regarding the use of standardized tests?

options.label: A
options.text: That test scores will result in sweeping and often negative changes for test-takers, sometimes with long-term life consequences.

options.label: B
options.text: That test scores will not accurately reflect academic learning.

options.label: C
options.text: That test scores will not be reliable or valid.

options.label: D
options.text: That test scores will not be used to inform instruction.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To capture excess neutrons and maintain a controlled chain reaction

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in storing spent nuclear fuel?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding a suitable location for storage

options.label: B
options.text: Cooling the fuel to prevent overheating

options.label: C
options.text: Isolating the fuel from the environment until it has safely decayed

options.label: D
options.text: Reusing the fuel in other applications

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential risk associated with storing spent nuclear fuel?

options.label: B
options.text: Security risk for nations due to the potential for plutonium to be mined and used to make bombs

title: Why are sloths so slow? - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: In 1796, Thomas Jefferson received a box of bones that he couldn't identify. What animal did he initially think the bones belonged to?
What was the approximate weight of the Megalonyx, a type of prehistoric ground sloth?
Why do researchers think that ground sloths may have gone extinct around 10,000 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to an oncoming ice age

options.label: B
options.text: Due to competition with other species, possibly humans

options.label: C
options.text: Due to a combination of an oncoming ice age and competition with other species

multiple-choice.question: How do sloths extract energy from their food, considering that leaves don't contain much energy?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a single-chambered stomach that quickly processes food

options.label: B
options.text: They have a multi-chambered stomach that takes up a third of their body and can spend days or weeks processing a meal

options.label: C
options.text: They supplement their diet with high-energy foods like fruits and seeds

options.label: D
options.text: They don't extract energy from their food, they just eat constantly

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the body temperature of sloths compared to other mammals?

options.label: A
options.text: It remains constant at all times

options.label: B
options.text: It fluctuates by about 1 degree Celsius

options.label: C
options.text: It fluctuates by about 5 degrees Celsius

options.label: D
options.text: It is always higher than the ambient temperature
